variant.question:
Concerning a fail-operational flight control system, in the event of a failure
1) the system will operate as a fail-passive system.
2) the landing is not completed automatically.
3) the landing is completed automatically.The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is
An automatic landing system necessitating that the landing be continued manually in the case of a system failure during an automatic approach is called fail

options.text: passive
redundant
active
reactive

variant.question:
Consider the automatic landing or autoland of an aeroplane
Which of the following items usually has/have a more restrictive limitation compared to a normal, manual landing? 1) headwind / crosswind 2) pressure altitude 3) runway contamination
Select an answer which contains all correct items!
A fail-operational hybrid landing system is fitted to an aircraft. This consists of a...

options.text: fail-passive automatic landing system and a secondary independent guidance system such as a head-up display (HUD). This enables the pilot to land manually if the automatic landing system fails.
fail-passive guidance system and a secondary independent landing system enabling automatic landing if the guidance system fails.
fail-operational landing system with a synthetic vision overlay, enabling better monitoring, and so a lower minimum RVR, than is possible with a simple fail-operational automatic landing system.

fail-operational landing system which, if the runway has NO low visibility approach aid, can overlay the enhanced vision system on the head-up display to allow continued operations below normal RVR minima.

variant.question: A fail-operational hybrid landing system is fitted to an aircraft. This consists of a...

options.text: fail-passive automatic landing system and a secondary independent guidance system such as a head-up display (HUD). This enables the pilot to land manually if the automatic landing system fails.

fail-operational landing system which, if the runway has no low visibility approach aid, can overlay the enhanced vision system on the head-up display to allow continued operations below normal RVR minima.
fail-passive guidance system and a secondary independent landing system enabling automatic landing if the guidance system fails.
fail-operational landing system with a synthetic vision overlay, enabling better monitoring, and so lower minimum RVR, than is possible with a simple fail-operational landing system.

variant.question: The autopilot system

options.text: includes a set of servo actuators that move the control surfaces.
instructs the Flight Director system to move the control surfaces.
controls the FMS.
instructs the FMS to move the control surfaces.

variant.question:
Concerning a fail-passive flight control system, in the event of a failure:

1 – there may be a significant deviation of flight path or attitude2 – there is no significant deviation of flight path or attitude3 – the landing is not completed automatically4 – the landing is completed automatically
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
An autopilot system:

options.text: must provide at least aircraft stabilization functions.
must provide at least aircraft guidance functions.
may provide automatic take-off functions.
must provide automatic take-off functions.

variant.question: An autopilot system:

options.text: must provide at least aircraft stabilisation functions.
may provide automatic take off functions.
must provide at least aircraft guidance functions.
must provide automatic take off functions.

variant.question: During a Cat III approach the 'FLARE' mode does not indicate. You have the required visual references. How can the approach be  completed in accordance with the regulations?

options.text: Complete the landing manually with the flight controls.
Reduce thrust and take control after landing.
Take control after the aircraft stops.
Take control after landing.

variant.question: A flight control system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure:

options.text: there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically.
there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude and the landing is completed automatically.
the system operates as a fail-operational hybrid landing system.
the system operates as a fail-operational system.

variant.question: Refer to figure 022-29. What are the different steps of the FLARE mode during an autoland? - FMS mode freeze at 150 ft RA - Vertical speed reduction at 100 ft RA - Autothrust disengagement at 70 ft RA - At 50 ft RA, disengagement of Glide Slope mode and engagement of the FLARE mode - Autothrust change from SPD to THR IDLE mode - Spoilers deployment
The sequence of the automatic landing comprises several phases, from final approach to touch-down. Transition from one phase to another is triggered by:

options.text: the radio altimeter.
the DME of the ILS.
the distance left before the touch down zone.
the altimeter set to the QNH.

variant.question: In the event of a failure, a fail-operational flight control system will operate as a

options.text: fail-passive system.
fail-redundant system.
fail-operational hybrid system.
fail-safe system.

variant.question: In automatic landing mode, when the 2 autopilots are used, the system is considered:

options.text: "fail passive" or without failure effect but with disconnection.
"fail hard" or with failure effect and disconnection.
"fail operational" or without failure effect with function always ensured.
"fail survival" or with minimized failure effect.

variant.question: During an auto coupled approach, where can the pilots verify the landing capability of the aircraft?

options.text: FMA that is located on each pilot's PFD.
FMA that is located on the MCP or FCU.
Thrust mode display that is located on the MCP or FCU.
Thrust mode display that is located on each pilot's PFD.

variant.question: The purpose of an automatic landing system is to:

options.text: make the landing possible in poor weather conditions.
have a smoother flare than when manually flying.
have a safer go-around in case of autopilot failure.
make the landing possible in case of a short runway.

variant.question: Concerning autoflight systems, what is a closed loop?

options.text: Continuous comparison between target and sensed value, computation and execution of required change, constant feedback about the effect of the manipulation.
Continuous monitoring of target value, computation of required change,  command to the pilot.
Continuous comparison between target and sensed value, computation and execution of required change.
Continuous monitoring of sensed value, computation of required change, command to the pilot, constant feedback about the effect of the manipulation.

variant.question: During a CAT III approach with NO decision height, you have passed the Alert Height, with NO visual references, when the ILS signal is lost. All other systems are working normally. As Co-Pilot and Pilot Monitoring (PM), what should you do?

options.text: Cancel the warning and immediately call “Go-Around”.
Wait for the Commander to decide whether to continue or Go-Around.
Continue normal PM monitoring duties until the aircraft has landed.
Call "Check FMA”.

variant.question:
When performing an automatic landing, some additional operational limitations may apply, like:

1 - maximum headwind or crosswind.2 - airport maximum pressure altitude.3 - runway conditions.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
Which instruments are required for automatic landing? - Radio altimeter - Barometric altimeter - Autopilot - Autothrottle
Which of the following aircraft components are incorporated in an Autoland system?

options.text: Autopilot(s), autothrust, and radio altimeter(s).
Flight controls, hydraulics, and radio altimeter(s).
Autopilot(s), autothrust, and control columns.
Flight controls, hydraulics, and control columns.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 During an autoland, what triggers the FLARE mode?

options.text: The radio altitude, when it reaches about 50 ft.
The glide slope mode.
The barometric altitude, when it reaches about 50 ft.
The localizer mode.

variant.question: An automatic landing system which can keep on operating without deterioration of its performances following the failure of one of the autopilots is called

options.text: fail operational.
fail passive.
fail redundant.
fail safe.

variant.question: A pilot is flying a CAT IIIA automatic approach, on an aeroplane equipped with a fail-passive system, and intends to autoland. After having acquired the required visual references, he/she notices that the FLARE has NOT engaged at the expected height. If continuation of the approach is permitted, he/she can...

options.text: take control of the aeroplane and complete the landing manoeuvre manually.
recycle automation and re-engage the autopilots to accomplish the automatic landing.
retard the thrust levers and take control of the aeroplane after touchdown.
announce the FMA failure and take control of the aeroplane after touchdown.

variant.question: How can you ascertain the landing capability in an auto-coupled approach?

options.text: Checking the FMA.
By checking the primary indications on the PFD.
Checking your current RA and the integrity of your RA.
By observing the primary indications on the PFD.

variant.question: How exactly is a fail-operational hybrid autopilot designed?

options.text: It consists of a primary fail-passive system with a secondary independent system (HUD), that allows the pilot to land manually in case of failure of the primary system.
It contains a fail-operational autopilot with a secondary vision enhancing device that allows a manual landing and roll-out.
It consists of a primary fail-operational system with a secondary system (HUD), that allows the pilot to land manually in case of failure of the primary system.
It contains an additional electric motor.

variant.question: When is an autoland procedure complete?

options.text: At the beginning of the ground roll.
At the flare.
At decision height.
At the inner marker.

variant.question: Which of the following elements can be checked by the pilot on the FMA: - engaged & armed a/p modes - auto landing capabilities - ACAS modes

Which of the following items is/are operational limitations in order to legally perform an autoland procedure? - Headwind / crosswind - Pressure altitude - Runway contamination Select an answer which contains all correct items:

options.text: You might intercept the G/S Before LOC and descend outside protected airspace.
You might get a GPWS warning.
You might intercept the LOC before G/S and fly outside protected airspace
You might undershoot the DA in case of missed approach.

variant.question: You are flying a CAT IIIB approach with no visual references, no decision height, and below the alert height. You get an ILS indication failure and all other parameters work as normal. What shall you do as the pilot monitoring?

options.text: Continue as pilot monitoring until landing.
Call “Check FMA”.
Wait for the captain to decide whether we should continue the approach or make a go-around.
Perform a go-around immediately.

variant.question: If a single element of the autoland system fails, is it still possible to safely use the autoland function but without the flare mode?

options.text: No, the flare mode is required for the complete autoland sequence.
Yes, as PF is always ready to fly manually and land the plane but only after passing the alert height.
No, because the rollout mode is frozen at 50 ft.
Yes, the pilot can take over manually for the flare even without visual contact.

variant.question: Selection of the lateral NAV button allows the autoflight system to navigate along a selected

options.text: ground track.
VOR radial.
DME arc.
magnetic heading.

variant.question: What is the purpose of autoland?

options.text: To be able to land in poor weather conditions.
To be able to land on a shorter runway.
To allow a smoother flare.
To engage a safer go around in case of missed approach.

variant.question: During an automatic landing, between 50 FT AGL and touch down, the autopilot maintains:

options.text: a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height.
a constant vertical speed.
a constant flight path angle with reference to the ground.
a vertical speed depending on the GPS height.

variant.question: During a Cat III approach with no decision height, the aircraft has passed the alert height. At this point there is a failure of one autopilot. The flight deck indications are that all systems are working normally. What should the co-pilot (Pilot Monitoring) do?

options.text: Continue normal PM monitoring duties until the aircraft has landed.
Advise the commander of the failure with a call such as 'autopilot failure'.
Call 'check FMA'
Call 'go around'.

variant.question: If, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically, such an automatic landing system is considered as

fail-safe.
fail-operational.

options.text: fail-passive.

Autopilot(s), autothrust, control column
Flight controls, hydraulics, radio altimeter
Flight controls, hydraulics, control column

options.text: fail-operational.
fail-soft.
fail-hard.
fail-passive.

variant.question: If, in the event of a failure, the approach, flare and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system, such an automatic landing system is considered as:

options.text: fail-operational.
fail-hard.
fail-soft.

variant.question: Following an automatic landing, with the ROLL OUT mode engaged, the autopilot:

options.text: controls the rudder and nose wheel steering to keep the aeroplane on the localiser centreline.
remains engaged until the runway is fully vacated.
performs an automatic go-around if speed is too high.
applies full reverse thrust to shorten the landing distance.

variant.question: Following an automatic landing, with the ROLL OUT mode engaged, the autopilot:

options.text: controls the rudder and nose wheel steering to keep the aeroplane on the localisercentreline.
applies full reverse thrust to shorten the landing distance.
performs an automatic go-around if speed is too high.
remains engaged until the runway is fully vacated.

variant.question: Which statement is correct concerning an autopilot system performing an autoland and engaged in the ROLL-OUT mode?

options.text: The autopilot uses the ILS signals and manipulates the rudder and nose wheel steering in order to stay on the runway centerline.
The autothrottle system automatically engages the reverse thrust for increased deceleration rate.
Automatically engages the go-around mode if the speed is excessive.
It remains engaged until the runway is vacated.

variant.question: A landing is performed automatically when the autopilot and autothrottle ensure good performance from/during the final approach

options.text: during the landing roll and sometimes until the aircraft comes to a complete stop.
until reaching 100 ft, height at which point the autopilot is automatically disconnected.
until the flare.
until reaching decision height.

variant.question: You are pilot monitoring on a CAT IIIB approach in LVO descending below alert height, when suddenly you get an ILS signal failure. Choose the correct action.

options.text: Provided that visual references have been established, the approach may be continued.
Call for a go around and continue with your monitoring duties.
Call «Check FMA».
Do not interrupt the pilot flying and confront the pilot when you have landed.

variant.question: Approaching top of descent, the destination aerodrome ATIS includes RVRs around 200 m, with Low Visibility Procedures (LVP) in force. The Commander's windscreen heat failed, with an annunciated alert, in the cruise. The screen is clear. What implications does the failure have on the briefing for the approach and landing?

options.text: A check of the FCOM is required, in case the defect causes a reduction in the aircraft's approach capability. Diversion, or a higher height and/or RVR might be necessary.
All aircraft systems are required to be serviceable for low visibility procedures, so diversion to a CAT I aerodrome will be necessary.
The autoland capability should NOT be affected by the windscreen heating failure, therefore NO action is necessary.

Because the failure was annunciated, if there is any consequent autoland capability downgrade, this will also be annunciated. In case autoland capability remains unchanged, a CAT III approach may be flown.

variant.question: Approaching top of descent, the destination aerodrome ATIS includes RVRs around 200m, with Low Visibility Procedures (LVP) in force. The Commander's windscreen heat failed, with an annunciated alert, in the cruise. The screen is clear. What implications does the failure have on the briefing for the approach and landing?

options.text: A check of the FCOM is required, incase the defect causes a reduction in the aircraft's approach capability. Diversion, or a higher height and/or RVR might be necessary.
All aircraft systems are required to be serviceable for low visibility procedures, so diversion to a CAT I aeordrome will be necessary.
The autoland capability should NOT be affected by the windscreen heating failure, therefore NO action is necessary.

Because the failure was annunciated, if there is any consequent autoland capability downgrade, this will also be annunciated. In case autoland capability remains unchanged, a CAT III approach may be flown.

variant.question: During the auto-land sequence, there’s a final approach phase and a touch down phase. The transition from one phase to another is triggered by the:

options.text: Radio altimeter.
Distance left from the touch-down zone.
QNH setting.
ILS/DME.

variant.question: An ILS signal failure occurs below the alert height. Provided that visual references have been established, how should the pilot react?

options.text: Cancel the warning and continue the approach.
Cancel the warning and go around.
Nothing will happen since all warnings including loss of ILS signal are inhibited below the alert height.
Only go around if ATC tells you.

variant.question: During a fully automatic landing, the autopilot:

options.text: and the autothrottle control the approach at least until the roll-out.
controls the approach (at least) until the flare, the pilot controls the power.
and the autothrottle control the approach at least until decision height.
and the autothrottle control the approach at least until the flare.

variant.question: An aeroplane is established on an ILS to perform an autoland. It is equipped with two autopilots, which are both engaged, and the autoland capability of the aeroplane is failoperational. ONE IRS fails when the aeroplane is passing 2000 ft with the only technical consequence being a downgraded landing capability. Given the information below, what are the consequences of this failure and what action should the pilots take? Approach minima: 0 ft Alert height: 100 ft

options.text: The landing capability is now fail-passive and the approach may be continued to revised minima if all the required actions can be completed in a timely manner.
Since the function of the autopilots is NOT affected by the failure of the IRS, the pilots can continue the approach to complete the autoland with fail-operational status.
There is an annunciation of the failure, and the landing capability is now fail passive. The pilots must prepare to perform a manual landing.

There is NO annunciation of the failure because the operation of the autopilots is NOT affected, but the landing capability is now limited fail-operational. The pilots should continue the approach to autoland.

variant.question: Approaching top of descent, the destination aerodrome ATIS includes RVRs around 200 m, with Low Visibility Procedures (LVP) in force. The Commander's windscreen heat failed, with an annunciated alert, in the cruise. Does it affect the autoland?

options.text: YES, since visual contact is important during the last stage of landing.
NO, it is not part of the autoland requirements.
YES, all aircraft systems are required to be serviceable for low visibility procedures.
The autoland capability should NOT be affected by the windscreen heating failure, therefore NO action is necessary.

variant.question: A semi-automatic landing system disconnects itself automatically

options.text: at the decision height.
when going around.
on ground.
at approximately 100 ft.

variant.question:
A landing will be considered to be performed in the AUTOMATIC mode when:
1) the autopilot maintains the airplane on the ILS beam until the decision height is reached then is disengaged automatically.
2) the autothrottle maintains a constant speed until the decision height is reached then is disengaged automatically.
3) the autopilot maintains the airplane on the ILS beam until the flare.
4) the autothrottle decreases the thrust when the height is approximately 30 ft.
5) the flare and the ground roll are performed automatically.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

A landing will be considered to be performed in the SEMI-AUTOMATIC mode when:
1) the autopilot maintains the airplane on the ILS beam until the decision height is reached then is disengaged automatically.
2) the autothrottle maintains a constant speed until the decision height is reached then is disengaged automatically.
3) the autopilot maintains the airplane on the ILS beam until the flare.
4) the autothrottle decreases the thrust when the height is approximately 30 ft.
5) the flare and the ground roll are performed automatically.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
The flight warning system (FWS) generates a caution message if

options.text: immediate crew awareness is required and subsequent crew action will be required.
immediate recognition and corrective or compensatory action by the crew is required.
crew awareness is required and corrective or compensatory action by the crew is immediately required.
crew awareness is required and subsequent crew action may be required.

variant.question:
The aural alert(s) associated with the mode 4 of the GPWS (unsafe terrain clearance while not in the landing configuration) is (are):
1. TOO LOW GEAR
2. TOO LOW TERRAIN
3. TOO LOW FLAPS
4. PULL UP
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

options.text: Disable the Glideslope functionality of the EGPWS.
Turn off the EGPWS.
Manually set the EGPWS to approach mode.
Turn off the ADIRU.

the aeroplane experiences an unexpected proximity to terrain, without landing-flap selected.
at too low altitude, the aeroplane has an excessive rate of descent.
the aeroplane experiences an unexpected proximity to the terrain, with landing gear retracted.

passes over the outer marker.
descends below a pre-set barometric altitude.
passes over the ILS inner marker.

mode 7

an audio alert sounds.
